Based on the search results, I found relevant information about Władysław Reymont's "Chłopi" (The Peasants) and its relationship to censorship and the periods mentioned. Here are the key findings:

## Reymont and Censorship in Partitioned Poland

Reymont changed his surname from "Rejment" to "Reymont" during his publishing debut, as it was supposed to protect him from potential trouble for having already published in Austrian Galicia a work not allowed under the Tsar's censorship. This demonstrates the censorship challenges faced by writers in the Russian partition of Poland.

## "Chłopi" and Communist Poland (PRL)

Władysław Reymont was popular in communist Poland due to his style of writing and the symbolism he used, including socialist concepts, romantic portrayal of the agrarian countryside and toned criticism of capitalism, all present in literary realism. This popularity in the PRL (People's Republic of Poland) suggests the work aligned with communist ideological preferences.

## Historical Context

The search results show that in the constitution of 1952, the name of the country was changed to People's Republic of Poland (Polska Rzeczpospolita Ludowa, PRL), and the political system was inspired by the Soviet system: the Communist reign was based on the Party's absolute power, nomenklatura, propaganda, censorship and security apparatus.

## About "Chłopi"

"Chłopi" (The Peasants) was Reymont's best-known work and award-winning four-volume novel, written partly in France between 1901 and 1908. Reymont was awarded the 1924 Nobel Prize in Literature for this work.

The search results provide some insight into the censorship issues Reymont faced during the partition period and how his work was later received in communist Poland, though more specific details about censorship of "Chłopi" itself during the interwar period or PRL would require additional research.
